Naming ==General Formula==: $\ce{C_nH_{2n+2}}$ Side chain-C-substituents or Radicals Alkyl group(R) Start numbering from C connected to [[ShortNames|PC]]. Alkane - 1H $\rightarrow$ Alkyl ($\ce{C_nH_{2n+1}}$)

LLR ==Lowest Locant(Carbon Branch) Rule==: Start numbering from that end from which locant is nearest. ![[Drawing 2022-03-31 05.11.47.excalidraw.svg]] 3,5-diethyl-2,8-dimethyldecane Lowest Locat Rule »> [[Lowest Sum Rule]]
LSR ==Lowest Sum Rule:== If $1^{st}$ locant is same from both sides, find sum of all locants and choose the lower one.
Structure $2^o$ prefix - $1^o$ prefix - Word Root - $1^o$ suffix - $2^o$ suffix ==$2^o$ suffix==: The senior-most [[Functional group]].
PC Parent Chain

Azeotropes Are binary mixtures having the ==same composition in liquid and vapour phase.== Boils at a ==constant temperature==. Solutions showing a large negative deviationfrom [[Raoult’s law]] forms a maximum boiling azeotropeat a specific composition.

Colligative Properties of Dilute [[Solutions]] ==Colligative Properties==: Properties which depend on the number of solute particles(irrespective of their nature) relative to the total number of particles present in the solution.

Concentration $$\boxed{Concentration = \frac{Solute}{Solvent} = \frac{Solute}{Solution}}$$ Fraction % (Percentage) PPM(Part per million) Out of 1 Out of 100 Out of $10^6$ $\frac{w}{w}=\frac{w_2}{w_{sol}}$ $\frac{w}{w}%=\frac{w_2}{w_{sol}}\times 100$ $\frac{w}{w}PPM=\frac{w_2}{w_{sol}}\times 10^6$ $\frac{w}{v}=\frac{w_2}{v_{sol}}$ $\frac{w}{v}%=\frac{w_2}{v_{sol}}\times 100$ $\frac{w}{v}PPM=\frac{w_2}{v_{sol}}\times 10^6$ $\frac{v}{v}=\frac{v_2}{v_{sol}}$ $\frac{v}{v}%=\frac{v_2}{v_{sol}}\times 100$ $\frac{v}{v}PPM=\frac{v_2}{v_{sol}}\times 10^6$ $$\boxed{\frac{W}{V}% = \frac{W}{W}%\times density} \tag{Formula}$$
Boiling point of composition for an ideal solution Boiling point of composition for a non-ideal solution In case of ==large negative deviation from [[Raoult’s law]]==, there is a minima in the VP vs.
Elevation in Boiling Point Boiling point of a liquid is the temperature at which the [[Vapour Pressure]] of the liquid becomes equal to the atmospheric pressure.
Henry’s Law Solubility of a gas in a liquid solvent increases in direct proportion to the partial pressure of the gas above the solution.
Ideal solution Solutions which obey [[Raoult’s law]] over the entire range of [[Concentration]]. Graph in case of ideal binary solutions.

INDEX [[Solutions]] [[Concentration]] [[Molarity]] [[Molality]] [[Solubility]] [[Henry’s Law]] [[Vapour Pressure]] [[Raoult’s law]] [[Ideal and Non-ideal Solution]] [[Concept of Boiling]] [[Azeotropes]]

Molality Molality(m): Moles of solute in 1 Kg solvent. $$\boxed{m=\frac{\text{Moles of solute}}{W_{1} (\text{Kg})}=\frac{\frac{W_2}{\text{Mw}2}}{\frac{W_1(g)}{1000}}}\tag{Formula}$$ $$\boxed{m=\frac{W{2\times}1000}{\text{Mw}{2\times}W_1(g)}}\tag{Formula}$$ Also, $$\boxed{m=\frac{x{2\times}1000}{x_{1\times}\text{Mw}_1}}\tag{Formula}$$ where $x_2$ and $x_1$ are [[Mole Fraction]].

Molarity Molarity(M) = Moles of solute in 1L solution. $$M=\frac{\text{Moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of solution (L)}}$$ $$\boxed{M=\frac{W_2}{\text{Mw}{2}\times V{sol} (ml)}}\tag{Formula}$$ $$\boxed{M=\frac{(\frac{W}{V}%)10}{\text{Mw}_2}}\tag{Formula}$$ $$\boxed{M=\frac{(\frac{W}{W}%)d,10}{\text{Mw}_2}}\tag{Formula}$$ where d = density of solution

Mole Fraction (x) Mole fraction of solute ($x_2$) = $x_2=\frac{n_2}{n_1+n_{2}}\tag{Formula}$ Mole fraction of solvent ($x_1$) = $x_2=\frac{n_1}{n_1+n_2}\tag{Formula}$ Sum of all fractions is always = 1 $$\boxed{x_1+x_2=1}$$$tb$
Raoult’ Law For a solution of volatile liquids, the partial vapour pressure of each component of the solution is directly proportional to their mole fraction in solution

RLVP On addition of a non-volatile solute to a volatile solvent, its [[Vapour Pressure]] decreases. Lowering of [[Vapour Pressure]] = $P_{1}^{o}-P_{1}$ Relative lowering of [[Vapour Pressure]] = $(\frac{P_{1}^{o}-P_{1}}{P_{1}^{o}})$

Solubility [[#Solubility of solid in a liquid|Solubility of solid in a liquid]] [[#Solubility of solid in a liquid#Effect of temperature:|Effect of temperature:]] [[#Solubility of solid in a liquid#Effect of pressure:|Effect of pressure:]] [[#Solubility of gas in a liquid.
Solutions Solutions are homogeneous mixturesof two or more than two components. The term homogeneous mixture signifies that composition and properties are uniform throughout the mixture.
Phase Diagrams A single phase is represented by an area on a phase diagram. The Red curve: (vaporization curve) equilibrium b/w the liq.
Vapour Pressure The vapour pressure of a liquid is the pressure exerted by its vapour when the liquid and vapour are in dynamic equilibrium.
